openai_summarised_points: • The People's Republic of China is characterized as a developing mixed socialist market economy that integrates industrial policies and strategic five-year plans to guide economic development.
• China ranks as the world's second largest economy by nominal GDP and has been the largest economy globally since 2016 when measured by purchasing power parity (PPP).
• In 2022, China contributed approximately 19% to the global economy in PPP terms and around 18% in nominal terms.

• The Chinese economy comprises state-owned enterprises (SOEs), mixed-ownership enterprises, and a substantial domestic private sector, which collectively contribute about 60% of GDP, 80% of urban employment, and 90% of new jobs.
• The economic system maintains a high degree of openness to foreign businesses, facilitating international trade and investment.

• China is the world's largest manufacturing industrial economy and the leading exporter of goods, widely recognized as the "powerhouse of manufacturing," "the factory of the world," and a "manufacturing superpower."
• The total manufacturing output of China exceeds that of the next nine largest manufacturing countries combined.
• Despite its manufacturing dominance, exports as a percentage of GDP have declined steadily to approximately 20%, indicating a decreasing relative importance of exports to the Chinese economy.
• China remains the largest trading nation globally and plays a significant role in international trade dynamics.

• The manufacturing sector is transitioning toward high-tech industries, including electric vehicles, renewable energy, telecommunications, and IT equipment, with services increasingly contributing to GDP.
• China is the world's largest exporter of high technology products.
• As of 2021, China allocates around 2.43% of its GDP to research and development across various sectors.
• The country is the fastest-growing consumer market worldwide and the second-largest importer of goods.
• China is the largest consumer of numerous commodities, accounting for about half of global metal consumption, and is a net importer of services.
• The country maintains bilateral free trade agreements with many nations and is a member of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).
• Among the world's 500 largest companies, 142 are headquartered in China.
• China hosts three of the world's top ten most competitive financial centers and three of the ten largest stock exchanges by market capitalization and trade volume.
• As of 2021, China’s financial assets totaled approximately $17.9 trillion, making it the second-largest in the world.
• In 2020, China was the largest recipient of foreign direct investment (FDI), attracting inflows of $163 billion; however, recent FDI inflows have sharply declined to negative levels.
• China has the second-largest outbound FDI, amounting to US$136.91 billion in 2019.
• Economic growth in China has slowed in the 2020s due to challenges such as a rapidly aging population, rising youth unemployment, and a property crisis.
• The Chinese labor force comprised 791 million workers in 2021, making it the largest globally, according to _The World Factbook_.
• As of 2022, China ranked second in the world in the total number of billionaires and second in millionaires, with approximately 6.2 million.
• China possesses the largest middle class worldwide, with over 500 million individuals earning more than RMB 120,000 annually.
• Public social expenditure in China was approximately 10% of GDP.

• According to Angus Maddison's estimates, the contribution of major economies to the world's GDP from 1 CE to 2003 CE shows that until the 18th century, China and India were the two largest economies by GDP output.
• GDP per capita in China from 1000 to 2018 demonstrates long-term economic fluctuations and growth trends over nearly a millennium.
• Historically, China was one of the world's leading economic powers during the two-millennia _Pax Sinica_ period, spanning from the 1st century until the 19th century.
• China accounted for approximately one-quarter to one-third of global GDP until the mid-1800s, reflecting its dominant economic position during this era.
• In 1820, China’s share of global GDP was one-third, coinciding with the beginning of the Industrial Revolution in Great Britain.
• In 1820, China’s GDP was six times larger than that of Britain, the largest European economy at the time, and nearly twenty times the GDP of the nascent United States.

• Following the Chinese Civil War, China’s economy was severely devastated; the defeated Nationalists fled to Taiwan, taking liquid assets such as gold, silver, and dollar reserves, which depleted China’s financial resources.
• By the end of the Chinese Civil War, commerce was destroyed, the national currency became worthless, and the economy reverted to barter-based transactions.
• The People's Republic of China (PRC) transitioned from one of the poorest countries to one of the largest economies in the shortest period in history, with rapid development starting after 1949.
• From 1949 until the economic reforms of 1978 under Deng Xiaoping, China’s economy was predominantly state-led with underground market activities.
• Economic reforms initiated under Deng Xiaoping marked a turning point, leading China to become the world’s fastest-growing major economy, with average growth rates of about 10% over three decades.
• Many scholars describe the Chinese economic model as a form of authoritarian capitalism, state capitalism, or party-state capitalism, especially under the leadership of Xi Jinping.
• Between 1978 and 2018, China lifted approximately 800 million people out of extreme poverty, the largest reduction in absolute numbers in human history.
• The percentage of China’s population living in extreme poverty decreased from 88.1% in 1981 to 0.2% in 2019.
• China’s current account surplus increased by a factor of 53 from $5.67 billion in 1982 to $317 billion in 2021.
• During this period, China evolved from low-wage sectors like clothing and footwear to producing sophisticated goods such as computers, pharmaceuticals, and automobiles.
• China’s manufacturing sector generated $3.7 trillion in real manufacturing value added, surpassing the combined output of the US, South Korea, Germany, and the UK.
• China benefits from one of the world’s largest domestic markets, extensive manufacturing scale, and highly developed supply chains.
• It hosts two of the global top 5 science and technology clusters: Shenzhen-Hong Kong-Guangzhou and Beijing, more than any other country.
• China’s sustained growth has been driven by export relations, its manufacturing sector, and a large low-wage workforce.
• China was the only major economy to experience GDP growth in 2020, with a 2.3% increase despite global economic downturns.
• In 2022, China faced one of its worst economic performances in decades due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
• The IMF predicted in 2023 that China would continue to be one of the fastest-growing major economies.

• China’s economy significantly contributes to rising global greenhouse gas emissions, thus impacting climate change, although its per capita emissions remain lower than developed economies like the United States.

• China's regional economies exhibit significant disparities due to an uneven transportation system, differences in natural and human resource availability, and variations in industrial infrastructure.
• These factors have led to notable variations in economic development across different regions of China.
• The economic growth of Shenzhen has been so prominent that it is often referred to as the "world's next Silicon Valley."
• Generally, coastal provinces in China have experienced more rapid economic development compared to inland regions.
• There are substantial disparities in per capita income among different regions in China.
• The three wealthiest regions are identified as the Yangtze Delta in East China, the Pearl River Delta in South China, and the Jing-Jin-Ji region in North China.
• The rapid development of these three regions is expected to significantly influence the overall Asian regional economy.
• Chinese government policies are aimed at removing obstacles to accelerate growth specifically in these wealthier regions.

• Under the "one country, two systems" policy, Hong Kong and Macau, formerly British and Portuguese colonies respectively, maintain distinct economic systems from mainland China.
• Both regions officially preserve a capitalist economic framework that operates independently from the socialist market economy of mainland China.
• Hong Kong's economy is characterized by free-market principles, a high degree of economic autonomy, and a significant financial services sector.
• Macau's economy is heavily reliant on tourism, particularly casino gaming, which constitutes a major portion of its GDP.
• The preservation of capitalist systems in Hong Kong and Macau is intended to ensure stability, attract foreign investment, and sustain their roles as international financial and tourism hubs.
• These regions operate under their own legal and economic systems, with Hong Kong having its own currency, the Hong Kong dollar, and Macau using the Macanese pataca.
• The economic policies of Hong Kong and Macau are governed by their respective local governments, with minimal interference from mainland China's central authorities in economic affairs.
• The special administrative regions (SARs) have their own customs, immigration, and legal systems, further reinforcing their economic independence.

• The maintenance of capitalist systems in Hong Kong and Macau is a core aspect of the "one country, two systems" policy, established to ensure their continued prosperity and stability within the People's Republic of China.
• The strategies for regional development in China are specifically targeted at relatively underdeveloped regions to address issues of uneven economic growth across the country.
• China Western Development is a regional strategy aimed at increasing the economic status of western provinces through targeted investment and the development of natural resources.

• The Revitalize Northeast China plan seeks to rejuvenate the industrial bases in the northeastern region, encompassing the three provinces of Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Liaoning, as well as five eastern prefectures of Inner Mongolia.
• The Rise of Central China Plan is designed to accelerate economic development in central regions, covering six provinces: Shanxi, Henan, Anhui, Hubei, Hunan, and Jiangxi.
• During the Cold War period, the Third Front strategy focused on developing the southwestern provinces of China to strengthen national defense and economic resilience.

• China, along with other major developing economies, experienced rapid economic growth from 1990 to 2013, as evidenced by the increasing GDP per capita at purchasing-power parity, with visual representation highlighting China's significant growth trend during this period.
• The Chinese economy is characterized by state-led investment and industrial policy, supported by a substantial sector of state-owned enterprises (SOEs).
• The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) describes China's economic system as a socialist market economy, integrating market mechanisms with state control.

• The Chinese central government formulates and implements five-year plans to guide economic development, outlining key priorities and policies; the current plan is the fourteenth five-year plan (2021–2025).
• The fourteenth five-year plan emphasizes consumption-driven growth and technological self-sufficiency, as China transitions from an upper middle-income economy to a high-income economy.
• The public sector plays a central role in China's economy, aligning with the Chinese government's goals to achieve the Two Centenaries:
• The first goal is to become a moderately prosperous society in all respects by 2021.

• The second goal is to modernize China into a "strong, democratic, civilized, harmonious and modern socialist country" by 2049, the 100th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China.

• Despite significant market reforms since the reform and opening-up period, China retains state control over the commanding heights of the economy, particularly in key industries such as infrastructure, telecommunications, and finance.
• Mechanisms through which the Chinese government maintains control include:
• Public property rights.
• Pervasive administrative involvement.
• CCP supervision of senior managers in key sectors.

• The Chinese government intervenes more actively in sectors where goods and services are socially and politically sensitive, notably in the commercial banking sector, compared to private equity, which involves fewer households.
• The state's involvement in finance, contracts, and resource allocation aims to mitigate market volatility and stabilize the economy.
• Local governments possess high levels of authority and autonomy in economic decision-making and have significantly contributed to national economic development.

• Local governments often provide incentives or subsidies to attract businesses, including tax incentives such as the "three tax-free and three half-tax" policy, allowing businesses to be exempt from corporate income tax for the first three years and pay half rate for the subsequent three years.

• In 2018, China’s share of global wealth was notable among world regions, and its export activity from 1990 to 2019 showed substantial growth, reflecting China's expanding role in international trade and economic influence.

• China's state-owned enterprises (SOEs) perform essential functions that benefit the state, including generating revenue for central and local governments through dividends and taxes, supporting urban employment, maintaining low prices for key input materials, channeling capital into targeted industries and technological sectors, facilitating redistribution to poorer interior and western provinces, and aiding the state's response to natural disasters, financial crises, and social instability, as noted by academic Wendy Leutert.
• According to Franklin Allen of Imperial College London, nearly 867,000 enterprises in China have some degree of state ownership.
• As of 2017, China has the highest number of SOEs globally, surpassing any other country, and also has the largest number of SOEs among large national companies.
• In 2019, SOEs accounted for over 60% of China's market capitalization.
• In 2020, China’s SOEs generated approximately US$15.98 trillion (101.36 trillion yuan) in GDP, representing 40% of the total GDP, which was US$15.98 trillion.
• The remaining 60% of China's GDP in 2020 was contributed by domestic and foreign private businesses and investments.
• As of the end of 2019, the total assets of all Chinese SOEs, including those in the financial sector, reached US$58.97 trillion.
• In 2015, the total assets of Chinese SOEs were valued at US$58.97 trillion.
• Ninety-one (91) Chinese SOEs were included in the 2020 Fortune Global 500 companies.
• As of 2023, private firms constitute only 37% of China's top-100 listed firms, according to data from the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

• There are ongoing disputes regarding the reliability of official Chinese economic data, with claims from both foreign sources and some Chinese sources that these statistics overstate China's economic growth.
• Several Western academics and institutions have argued that China's actual economic growth is higher than official figures suggest.
• The Economist Intelligence Unit acknowledges that China's GDP data appears "smoothed," but considers both nominal and real GDP figures to be broadly accurate.
• Conversely, some analysts contend that reported GDP growth figures are irreconcilable with other data from China, raising questions about their validity.
• In 2024, the United States Department of Agriculture ceased reliance on official Chinese government data due to concerns over its reliability.

• According to 2007 documents obtained by WikiLeaks, Liaoning Party Secretary and future Premier Li Keqiang expressed significant skepticism about China's GDP estimates, describing them as "man-made" and unreliable, and stated that data releases, especially GDP numbers, should be used "for reference only."
• Li Keqiang developed the Li Keqiang index as an alternative measure of Chinese economic performance, which uses three variables he preferred, instead of official GDP figures.
• Chinese provinces and cities have long been suspected of "cooking" their economic data, with local officials' performance often judged based on economic performance metrics.

• Local governments face increased scrutiny over data manipulation, with CCP General Secretary Xi Jinping stating that economic data forgery "not only hurt our judgment of the economic situation, but also seriously undermined the Communist Party's ideas and truth-seeking style."

• Gao Shanwen, chief economist at SDIC Securities and government adviser, stated at a Peterson Institute event on 12 December 2024 that "we do not know the true number of China’s real growth figure," estimating actual growth at about 2% annually compared to the official 5%.
• Gao predicted that China's economy would grow by 3–4% annually over the next several years, but maintained that the official number would always be around 5%.

• Gao's comments reportedly led to a government ban on him speaking publicly; however, he did not lose his job, but the Securities Association of China ordered brokerages and investment firms to ensure their economists "play a positive role," with non-compliance risking termination.
• In January 2025, Xi Jinping's aide Cai Qi ordered propaganda officials to block negative economic news.

• A 2019 research paper published by the Brookings Institution suggested that adjusting China's GDP time series using value-added tax data—considered highly resistant to fraud—indicates that China's economic growth may have been overstated by 1.7% annually between 2008 and 2016, leading to an overstatement of the economy's size by 12–16% in 2016.

• Multiple Western academics and institutions support the view that China's economy is likely underestimated; for example, a paper by the US-based National Bureau of Economic Research claims China's growth may be higher than official statistics indicate.

• An article by Hunter Clark, Maxim Pinkovskiya, and Xavier Sala-i-Martin (2018, Elsevier Science Direct) used satellite-recorded nighttime lights as an unbiased predictor of economic activity, suggesting China's actual growth rate exceeds official reports.
• Satellite measurements of light pollution are employed by some analysts to model Chinese economic growth, indicating that official data are more reliable but likely smoothed.

• According to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, China's official statistics are of relatively high quality compared to other developing and middle-income countries, with China ranking at the 83rd percentile of middle and low-income countries in 2016, up from the 38th percentile in 2004.

• A study by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco found that China's official GDP figures are "significantly and positively correlated" with external measures such as import and export data, suggesting that China's official growth figures are not significantly understated.

• The Rhodium Group, an independent research think tank, has consistently questioned the accuracy of China's official GDP figures, arguing that recent overstatements are due to structural issues and "authority bias" in official data.

• Rhodium estimates that China's actual GDP growth in 2024 ranged between 2.4% and 2.8%, substantially lower than the official claim of 4.8%, indicating an overstatement of approximately 2 percentage points annually since at least 2022.
• If Rhodium's adjustments are accurate, China's economy could be around 10% smaller than reported since their tracking began, equating to a reduction of approximately $1.7 trillion in GDP.

• The discrepancies are attributed to collapsing real estate activity, declining local government investment, and weak household consumption, which official data fail to fully capture, thus misleadingly portraying stable growth.
• In 2024, property sector declines and infrastructure investment reductions were significant, yet official figures suggested stable contributions from these sectors.
• Official data also overstate government fiscal spending and household consumption, which Rhodium argues are critical indicators of economic health, and these were actually far weaker than reported.

• A 2015 study by Daniel H. Rosen and Beibei Bao indicated that China's GDP in 2008 was actually 13–16% larger than official data, and the 2013 GDP was closer to $10.5 trillion rather than the official $9.5 trillion.

• Arvind Subramanian, a former IMF economist and Peterson Institute senior fellow, estimated that China's GDP by Purchasing Power Parity in 2010 was about $14.8 trillion, significantly higher than the IMF's official estimate of $10.1 trillion, implying that China's GDP was underestimated by approximately 47%.
• In 2022, China's total government debt was approximately CN¥ 94 trillion (US$ 14 trillion), representing about 77.1% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• In 2014, concerns were raised by many analysts regarding the overall size of China's government debt.
• At the end of 2014, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reported that China's general government gross debt-to-GDP ratio was 41.44 percent.

• A 2015 IMF report concluded that China's public debt remained relatively low and on a stable trajectory, passing all standard stress tests except in scenarios involving contingent liability shocks, such as large-scale bank recapitalizations or financial system bailouts, which could be triggered by a potential rise in non-performing loans (NPLs) from deleveraging.
• According to the 2019 balance of payments report by the State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE), the external debt balance of the entire Chinese government at year-end was 2% of GDP.
• Chinese authorities have dismissed analysts' concerns, asserting that "the country still has room to increase government debt."
• Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, in 2016, commented that China's debt issue is primarily an "internal" problem, noting that the majority of borrowings are issued in local currency.
• A 2019 survey conducted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) found that China's corporate debt levels are higher than those of other major countries.
• Shadow banking in China has increased, posing risks to the financial system; this off-the-books debt is considered a grey area with significant estimates.
• The estimated amount of off-balance-sheet debt for local governments alone is as high as US$ 9 trillion or 63 trillion yuan, up from approximately 30 trillion yuan in 2020.
• Despite rapid expansion of China's economy, its regulatory environment has lagged behind economic growth.
• Since Deng Xiaoping's open market reforms, the proliferation of new businesses has outstripped the government's capacity to regulate effectively.
• This regulatory gap has led businesses to adopt drastic measures to boost profit margins, often compromising consumer safety.
• The problem of insufficient regulation and safety concerns became more prominent in 2007.
• In 2007, the United States imposed a number of restrictions on problematic Chinese exports to address safety and quality issues.
• The Chinese technology sector has been characterized by dominance of a few large entities, notably Ant Group and Tencent.

• The Xi Jinping Administration has undertaken efforts to enforce economic competition rules within this sector, including launching probes into major companies such as Alibaba and Tencent by Chinese economic regulators.
• During the 2020–2021 period, the administration's crackdown on tech giants and internet companies was part of a broader reform spree aimed at regulating the sector.
• These regulatory actions were followed by calls from the Politburo urging the elimination of monopolistic practices by large commercial retail firms, specifically targeting companies like Alibaba.
• In March 2021, Xi Jinping publicly declared that China would strengthen its antitrust enforcement to promote the healthy and sustainable development of the platform economy.
• As part of this initiative, two significant institutional changes occurred:
• In November 2021, China upgraded the bureaucratic status of the State Administration for Market Regulation’s (SAMR) antitrust bureau, elevating its authority and importance.
• In June 2022, China enacted major amendments to the Anti-Monopoly Law, including explicit provisions aimed at regulating the platform economy and addressing monopolistic behaviors within it.

• Pork is a significant component of the Chinese economy, with an average per capita consumption of 90 grams per day.
• In 2007, China experienced a steep rise in pork prices, primarily driven by a global increase in the price of animal feed.
• The rise in animal feed prices was associated with increased production of ethanol from corn, which contributed to the surge in pork prices.
• The escalation in pork prices was further exacerbated by increased production costs combined with rapidly rising wages, leading to inflationary pressures in the sector.
• In response to the rising pork prices, the Chinese government implemented subsidies targeting specific vulnerable groups, including students and the urban poor.
• The government also called for increased pork production to stabilize prices.
• Consideration was given to releasing pork from the nation’s strategic pork reserve as a measure to control inflation and stabilize the market.
• Chinese investment has historically exhibited a highly cyclical pattern, characterized by periods of rapid expansion followed by contraction.
• The majority of investment in China is conducted by entities that are at least partially state-owned, with most controlled by local governments.
• Booms in Chinese investment are primarily driven by perverse incentives at the local-government level, rather than purely market-driven factors.
• Unlike entrepreneurs in a free-market economy, Chinese local officials are mainly motivated by political considerations, particularly their performance evaluations.
• Local officials’ performance assessments are largely based on GDP growth within their jurisdictions, incentivizing them to promote large-scale investment projects.
• A typical investment cycle in China begins with a relaxation of central government credit and industrial policies, which facilitates increased local investment activity.

• During these periods, local governments push investment aggressively through state-sector entities they directly control and by offering incentives to private investors and enterprises outside their jurisdictions.
• The resulting investment boom exerts upward pressure on prices and can lead to shortages of key inputs such as coal and electricity, exemplified by shortages in 2003.
• As inflation rises to levels that threaten social stability, the central government intervenes by tightening enforcement of industrial and credit policies.
• Central government measures include halting projects that proceeded without proper approvals and restricting bank lending to specific investor groups.
• Following intervention, credit becomes tight, leading to a decline in investment growth and the end of the boom cycle.
• China's unemployment situation has become a significant concern, especially among its youth population.
• As of late 2024, the official urban surveyed unemployment rate stood at 5.0%, indicating relative stability in urban employment figures.
• The annual unemployment rate was projected to decrease slightly from 5.2% in 2023 to 5.1% in 2024.
• Youth unemployment, however, presents a more alarming scenario, with the official rate for individuals aged 16 to 24 peaking at 21.3% in mid-2023.
• By November 2024, the official youth unemployment rate had declined to 16.1%.
• Independent estimates suggest that the actual youth unemployment rate may have been substantially higher than official figures, with some analysts proposing it could have reached as high as 46.5%.
• Other experts have speculated that youth unemployment may have approached or even exceeded 50%.

• Reports have emerged indicating the existence of "fake jobs," which are positions that exist only on paper and do not provide meaningful work or income, used to artificially lower official unemployment statistics.
• The high youth unemployment and underemployment issues are exacerbated by a slowing Chinese economy, a prolonged property market crisis, and insufficient demand for skilled labor.
• Many young Chinese have responded to these challenges by "lying flat" (a term describing withdrawal from active workforce participation) or retreating from the labor market altogether.
• The Chinese government is undertaking reforms aimed at improving labor conditions and stimulating economic growth, with a target of achieving 5% GDP growth.
• Despite these efforts, youth unemployment and underemployment remain critical challenges for policymakers and society, impacting social stability and economic development.
• China has the world's largest total banking sector assets, approximately $45.838 trillion (309.41 trillion CNY), with $42.063 trillion in total deposits and other liabilities.
• The majority of China's financial institutions are state-owned and governed, emphasizing government control over the financial sector.
• The primary instruments of China's financial and fiscal control are the People's Bank of China (PBC) and the Ministry of Finance, both operating under the authority of the State Council.

• The People's Bank of China (PBC), established in 1950 as the successor to the Central Bank of China, gradually took over private banks and performs functions similar to both central and commercial banks.

• The PBC issues currency, controls circulation, disburses budgetary expenditures, administers accounts, payments, and receipts of government organizations, and supervises their financial performance in line with government economic plans.

• The PBC is also responsible for managing international trade and overseas transactions, including remittances by overseas Chinese, which are managed by the Bank of China (BOC), which maintains branch offices in several countries.

• Other significant financial institutions include the China Development Bank (CDB), which funds economic development and foreign investment; the Agricultural Bank of China (ABC), which supports the agricultural sector; the China Construction Bank (CCB), responsible for capitalizing investment and industrial/construction enterprises; and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), which handles commercial transactions and acts as a savings bank.
• China founded the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank in 2015 and the Silk Road Fund in 2014, both aimed at fostering investment and financial support along the Belt and Road Initiative.

• China's economic reforms significantly expanded the banking system's role; although theoretically any enterprise or individual can obtain loans outside the state plan, approximately 75% of state bank loans are directed to State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs).
• As of 2011, outstanding loans to local governments amounted to approximately 14 trillion Yuan, with much believed to be nonperforming.

• Increasing funds are available through banks for economic and commercial purposes, with foreign capital sources also rising, including loans from the World Bank, UN programs, Japan, and other countries, with Hong Kong serving as a major conduit for investment.

• On 23 February 2012, the PBC indicated a move towards liberalizing capital markets by circulating a ten-year timetable, leading to Shenzhen banks launching cross-border yuan remittances for individuals, marking a significant relaxation of previous capital controls.
• China hosts four of the world's top ten most competitive financial centers: Shanghai, Hong Kong, Beijing, and Shenzhen, more than any other country.
• China has three of the world's ten largest stock exchanges—Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Shenzhen—by market capitalization and trade volume.
• As of 12 October 2020, the combined market capitalization of mainland Chinese stock markets (Shanghai and Shenzhen) exceeded US$10 trillion, with about US$5.9 trillion, excluding Hong Kong.

• By June 2020, foreign investors had purchased US$440 billion worth of Chinese stocks, representing approximately 2.9% of the total market value, with US$156.6 billion bought in the first half of 2020 alone.
• China's bond market surpassed US$15.4 trillion as of September 2020, ranking above Japan and the UK and second only to the U.S. (US$40 trillion).
• As of September 2020, foreign holdings of Chinese bonds reached US$388 billion, accounting for 2.5% of the total bond market, with a year-on-year increase of 44.66%.
• As of 2024, China possesses the second largest equity markets and futures markets globally, and the third largest bond market worldwide.
• China's stock market exchanges include the Beijing Stock Exchange, the Shanghai Stock Exchange (which includes the STAR Market), the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
• Despite its large size, China's stock market is considered relatively underdeveloped compared to other sectors of its economy.

• To be listed on China's stock exchanges, companies must meet several criteria: demonstrate good financial standing (including sustained profitability), exhibit solid corporate governance (such as a board of independent directors, a supervisory board, and auditing), have no history of misreporting or fraud, and possess a market capitalization of at least US$4 million.

• The Chinese government regulates initial public offerings (IPOs), encouraging them during periods of high market valuation to prevent overheating, and restricting them during market downturns to cool prices.
• When China's stock markets re-opened in 1990 during the PRC period, most listed companies were state-owned enterprises (SOEs), marking an experiment in applying market discipline to SOEs.
• The Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges were initially under municipal control and referred to as "experimental points" until 1997.
• In 1997, the central government took control of these exchanges, affirming their legitimate role within the socialist market economy.
• In 2015, a significant stock market crash in China resulted in a loss of approximately US$2 trillion in global stock market value.
• The renminbi ("people's currency") is the official currency of China, denominated as the yuan, and subdivided into 10 jiao or 100 fen.
• The currency is issued by the People's Bank of China, which serves as China's monetary authority.
• The ISO 4217 abbreviation for the renminbi is CNY, though it is also commonly abbreviated as "RMB."
• As of 2005, outside observers generally considered the yuan to be undervalued by approximately 30–40%.
• In 2017, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) stated that the yuan was correctly valued, indicating a reassessment of its exchange rate valuation.
• The renminbi operates within a floating exchange-rate system, primarily managed against the US dollar.
• On 21 July 2005, China revalued its currency by 2.1% against the US dollar.
• Since the 2005 revaluation, China has transitioned to an exchange rate system referencing a basket of currencies, allowing the renminbi to fluctuate daily by up to 0.5%.
• There exists a complex relationship between China's balance of trade, inflation (measured by the consumer price index), and the value of its currency.
• Despite allowing the yuan to "float," China's central bank retains decisive control over its value relative to other currencies.
• In 2007, inflation, driven by rising prices for meat and fuel, was likely linked to the global increase in commodities used as animal feed or fuel.
• The rapid appreciation of the yuan permitted in December 2007 was possibly aimed at mitigating inflation by increasing the currency's value.

• An empirical study published in the International Review of Economics & Finance in 2010 by Mete Feridun and colleagues from the University of Greenwich Business School provided evidence that financial development promotes economic growth in China.
• During the week of 10 August 2015, amidst a slowing Chinese economy and a strengthening US dollar, the People's Bank of China devalued the renminbi by approximately 5%.
• The 2015 devaluation was achieved by pegging the official rate to closing market rates.

• Achieving a market-based "representative" exchange rate against the US dollar is a requirement for a currency to be designated as having Special Drawing Rights (SDR) by the IMF, which is a goal for China.
• Since the late 2000s, China has actively sought to internationalize the renminbi.
• By 2013, the RMB had become the 8th most widely traded currency in the world.
• In November 2015, IMF Director Christine Lagarde announced support for including the yuan in the SDR currency basket, ahead of G-20 and IMF meetings.
• The IMF's support led to official approval at the 30 November 2015 IMF meeting for the yuan's inclusion in the SDR basket.
• The internationalization process of China's economy continues to influence its economic forecasts, which are officially published through the Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) since 2005.
• According to Fortune Global, 135 of the world's 500 largest companies are headquartered in China.
• As of 2023, mainland China and Hong Kong collectively host 324 of the largest listed companies measured by revenue in the Fortune Global 2000, ranking second globally.
• China is home to more than two hundred privately held technology startups, known as tech unicorns, each with a valuation exceeding $1 billion.
• China holds the highest number of tech unicorns in the world, reflecting its significant presence in the global technology startup ecosystem.

• China is the world's largest producer and consumer of agricultural products, with approximately 300 million Chinese farm workers primarily working on small plots of land comparable in size to U.S. farms.
• Virtually all arable land in China is dedicated to food crop cultivation.
• China is the leading global producer of rice and is among the principal sources of wheat, corn (maize), tobacco, soybeans, potatoes, sorghum, peanuts, tea, millet, barley, oilseed, pork, and fish.
• Major non-food crops include cotton, other fibers, and oilseeds, which contribute a small proportion to China’s foreign trade revenue.
• Agricultural exports such as vegetables, fruits, fish, shellfish, grain, and meat products are primarily exported to Hong Kong.
• Despite having only 75% of the cropland area of the United States, China produces about 30% more crops and livestock than the U.S. due to intensive cultivation practices.
• China aims to further increase agricultural production through improvements in plant stocks, fertilizers, and technology.
• According to government statistics from 2005, after a decline in farm crop yields in 2000, agricultural output has been increasing annually.
• FAO data from 2005 shows wheat production from 1961 to 2004, with a trend of growth in crop yields over the decades.
• In 2022, the United Nations World Food Programme reported that China fed 18% of the world's population using only 7% of the world's arable land.
• Animal husbandry is the second most important component of Chinese agriculture, with China being the world's leading producer of pigs, chickens, and eggs.
• China also maintains sizable herds of sheep and cattle, with increased emphasis on livestock output since the mid-1970s.
• The country has a longstanding tradition of ocean and freshwater fishing and aquaculture, with pond raising playing a significant role in supplementing fisheries.
• China possesses an extensive fishing fleet, estimated between 200,000 and 800,000 boats, some operating as far as Argentina, with growth largely driven by government subsidies.
• Environmental challenges such as floods, droughts, and erosion threaten Chinese agriculture; efforts at reforestation have been insufficient, leaving forest resources relatively limited.

• Principal forests are located in the Qin Mountains, central mountains, and the Yunnan–Guizhou Plateau; however, much timber is sourced from Heilongjiang, Jilin, Sichuan, and Yunnan due to inaccessibility of Qinling forests.
• Western China (Tibet, Xinjiang, Qinghai) has limited agricultural significance, mainly focusing on floriculture and cattle raising.
• Rice dominates in southern provinces, often yielding two harvests annually; in northern regions, wheat is the primary crop.
• In central China, wheat and rice are both prominent crops, competing for dominance.
• Millet and kaoliang (grain sorghum) are mainly cultivated in the northeast and some central provinces, which also produce significant quantities of barley.
• Most soybean production occurs in northern and northeastern China; maize is grown in central and northern regions; tea is primarily produced in warm, humid southern hills.
• Cotton is extensively cultivated in central provinces and to a lesser extent in the southeast and north; tobacco is mainly produced in central and southern areas.
• Other notable crops include potatoes, sugar beets, and oilseeds.
• In the past decade, the Chinese government has promoted agricultural mechanization and land consolidation to increase yields and offset rural labor migration to cities.
• The annual growth rate of agricultural mechanization in China is approximately 6.4%, with the integrated mechanization rate reaching nearly 60% by 2014.
• Mechanization rates for wheat exceeded 90%, and maize approached 80% by 2014.
• Use of high-tech equipment such as unmanned aerial vehicles for crop spraying has increased within agricultural cooperatives.
• About half of China's cultivated land is irrigated, reflecting progress in water conservancy efforts.
• The late 1970s and early 1980s marked significant economic reforms, including the shift to household responsibility systems, phasing out collectivized agriculture, and liberalizing price controls.

• Reforms also included fiscal decentralization, privatization of state enterprises, development of private service and manufacturing sectors, establishment of a diversified banking system with substantial state control, creation of a stock market, and opening the economy to foreign trade and investment.
• In 2010, China became the world's largest market for construction and has maintained this status through at least 2024.
• The real estate industry constitutes approximately 20% of the Chinese economy.
• As of 2023, real property accounts for 60% of Chinese household assets, indicating a significant reliance on real estate for wealth accumulation.
• Also in 2023, China has the highest rate of home ownership globally, with 90% of urban households owning their homes.

• Compared to other countries, investing in stock markets and alternative assets is more difficult in China due to strict currency controls, making real estate a primary avenue for wealth growth and preservation.
• Many Chinese citizens own multiple properties, as real estate is one of the few accessible means to grow and safeguard wealth within the country.
• Economists have speculated about a potential property bubble in China, driven by high levels of real estate investment and valuation.

• On 16 July 2020, the Wall Street Journal reported that the Chinese housing market had grown to a total value of US$52 trillion, surpassing the US housing market size before the 2008 financial crisis.
• Despite concerns over a housing bubble, many individuals continue to invest heavily in real estate assets.

• On 19 December 2021, McKinsey Global Institute reported that China's net worth reached $120 trillion in 2020, surpassing the United States' $89 trillion, largely driven by a booming real estate market that elevated property values.
• In 2017, China's electricity production reached approximately 6.5 trillion kilowatt-hours (kWh).
• In 2020, China's electricity consumption was approximately 7.762 trillion kWh, with exports totaling 21.8 billion kWh and imports at 6.2 billion kWh in 2015.
• As of 2023, the breakdown of electricity generation sources was: coal 60.5%, hydro 13.2%, wind 9.4%, solar 6.2%, nuclear 4.6%, natural gas 3.3%, and bioenergy 2.2%.
• China's oil production in 2022 was 3,527,000 barrels per day (bbl/d), equivalent to 560,700 cubic meters per day (m3/d).
• Oil consumption in 2005 was 6,534,000 bbl/d (1,038,800 m3/d), with an expected increase to 9,300,000 bbl/d (1,480,000 m3/d) by 2030.
• Oil exports in 2005 were 443,300 bbl/d (70,480 m3/d).
• Oil imports in 2022 were 10,170,000 bbl/d (1,617,000 m3/d), with net imports in 2005 at 2,740,000 barrels per day (436,000 m3/d).
• China's proved oil reserves as of January 1, 2006, were approximately 16.3 gigabarrels (Gbbl), equivalent to 2.59×10^9 m3.
• Natural gas production in 2005 was estimated at 47.88 km3, with consumption at 44.93 km3, and exports at 2.944 km3; imports were zero in 2005.
• As of January 1, 2006, China's proved natural gas reserves totaled approximately 1,448 km3.
• Historically, subsidies for energy commodities grew substantially in the late 1970s and 1980s, significantly influencing production and consumption patterns.

• Since 1980, China's energy production has grown dramatically, with about 80% generated from fossil fuels at thermal plants, 17% from hydroelectric sources, and approximately 2% from nuclear energy, mainly in Guangdong and Zhejiang.

• Despite rich overall energy potential, most resources remain underdeveloped and geographically distant from major industrial centers; the northeast is rich in coal and oil, central north China has abundant coal, and the southwest has significant hydroelectric potential.
• Industrialized regions such as Guangzhou and the Lower Yangtze around Shanghai have insufficient local energy resources, and heavy industry is not concentrated near most resource-rich areas.
• China aims to shift its energy mix away from coal (which accounts for 70–75% of energy consumption) toward oil, natural gas, renewable energy, and nuclear power due to environmental concerns.
• Over the past five to ten years, China has closed thousands of coal mines to reduce overproduction, decreasing coal output by over 25% as of 2023.
• As of 2023, solar power has become cheaper than coal-fired power in China.
• China has been a net oil importer since 1993, primarily sourcing from the Middle East, with imported oil constituting about 20% of processed crude.
• By 2010, China’s net oil imports were projected to reach 3.5 million barrels per day (560,000 m3/d).
• China has invested in oil fields globally, including in Central Asia and Kazakhstan, to diversify its oil sources.

• China’s natural gas production is targeted for expansion; it accounted for only 3% of total energy consumption, with plans in the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005) to increase its share from 2% to 4%, compared to 25% in the U.S. energy sector.

• Since the early 2000s, China’s renewable energy sector has rapidly developed, facilitating international cooperation and technology transfer to developing countries; as of 2023, China is the world’s leading producer of solar panels and wind turbines.

• The 11th Five-Year Program (2006–2010), approved in March 2006, emphasized energy conservation, renewable energy development, and environmental protection, aiming for a 20% reduction in energy consumption per unit of GDP by 2010.
• The program prioritized transitioning from coal to cleaner energy sources, including oil, natural gas, renewables, and nuclear power, and improving energy efficiency and clean coal technology.
• China’s hydroelectric capacity, exemplified by the Three Gorges Dam, was projected to reach 18 gigawatts (GW) when fully operational in 2009.
• The share of nuclear-generated electricity was projected to increase from 1% in 2000 to 5% by 2030.
• China’s renewable energy law, enacted in 2006, mandated that 10% of the country’s energy come from renewable sources by 2020.

• By 2010, rising wages and living standards increased energy demand, prompting efforts to improve efficiency and expand renewable energy use, including the closure of over 1,000 inefficient power plants.
• Despite these efforts, projections indicated a continued dramatic rise in carbon emissions from fossil fuel combustion.
• China accounts for approximately 25% of global greenhouse gas emissions today, although it is not the largest cumulative emitter historically.

• In 2019, China’s per capita CO2-equivalent emissions were 9 tonnes per year, surpassing the European Union’s 7.6 tonnes but remaining below the OECD average of 10.7 tonnes and the U.S. average of 17.6 tonnes.
• The carbon intensity of China’s GDP remains relatively high, indicating significant emissions per unit of economic output.

• Experts like Nicholas Stern and Fergus Green have suggested that China should shift towards more advanced, low-carbon industrial development and allocate resources toward innovation and R&D to mitigate environmental pollution and long-term socioeconomic costs.
• Despite public goals, China continues to build numerous coal-fired power plants, potentially increasing its carbon emissions further.
• As of 2022, over 200 types of minerals are actively explored or mined in the People's Republic of China (PRC).
• Mineral resources in China are widely distributed across the country but not evenly.
• The Chinese economy and exports are not heavily dependent on the mining industry as a whole; however, the industry is critically important to various subnational governments within the PRC.
• Mining in China is extensively regulated and overseen by multiple regulatory bodies.
• The Chinese state owns all mineral rights nationwide, regardless of land ownership where minerals are located.
• Mining rights can be acquired through government approval, which involves paying prospecting and mining fees.
• During the Mao Zedong era, mineral exploration and mining activities were limited to state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and collectively-owned enterprises; private exploration was largely prohibited.
• The industry was opened to private enterprises during China's economic reforms in the 1980s, leading to increased marketization in the 1990s.
• In the mid-2000s, the Chinese government aimed to consolidate the mining industry due to concerns about resource underutilization, workplace safety issues, and environmental damage.
• During this consolidation period, state-owned enterprises purchased smaller privately-owned mines.
• China's mining industry experienced significant growth from the early 2000s to 2012, a period often referred to as the "golden decade" of mining in China.
• China possesses abundant hydroelectric potential due to its extensive river network and mountainous terrain.
• The majority of China's hydroelectric capacity is located in the southwest region, where coal resources are limited but energy demand is rapidly increasing.

• The hydroelectric potential in northeastern China is relatively small; however, it was in this region that the first hydroelectric stations were constructed by the Japanese during their occupation of Manchuria.
• The Three Gorges Dam, one of China's most significant hydroelectric projects, took thirteen years to build and cost approximately $24 billion.
• The dam spans the Yangtze River and was essentially completed in 2006.
• In 2018, the Three Gorges Dam produced over 100 terawatt-hours (TWh) of electricity.
• China is highly endowed with mineral resources, with coal being the most important among them.
• China's mineral resources include large reserves of coal and iron ore, along with adequate to abundant supplies of nearly all other industrial minerals.
• Coal deposits are widely scattered across China, with some types found in every province.
• The majority of coal reserves are located in the northern part of China, particularly in the province of Shanxi, which is believed to contain about half of the country's total coal reserves.
• Other significant coal-bearing provinces include Heilongjiang, Liaoning, Jilin, Hebei, and Shandong.
• Besides the northern provinces, substantial quantities of coal are present in Sichuan, with important deposits also found in Guangdong, Guangxi, Yunnan, and Guizhou.
• A large portion of China's coal reserves consists of good quality bituminous coal, with significant deposits of lignite as well.
• Anthracite coal is present in several locations, notably in Liaoning, Guizhou, and Henan, but overall, it is not very significant in terms of total reserves.

• To promote a more even distribution of coal supplies and alleviate pressure on the inadequate transportation network, Chinese authorities promoted the development of numerous small, locally operated mines nationwide.
• This initiative intensified after the 1960s, resulting in the establishment of thousands of small pits that produce more than half of China's coal.
• The coal produced by these small mines is typically expensive and primarily used for local consumption.
• The proliferation of small, unregulated mines has led to less stringent safety measures, causing several thousand deaths annually.
• Coal constituted approximately 70% of China's energy consumption in 2005 and decreased to 55% in 2021.
• China is the world's largest producer and consumer of coal.
• As China's economy continues to grow, its demand for coal is projected to increase significantly.
• Although coal's percentage share of China's overall energy consumption is expected to decline, total coal consumption in absolute terms is anticipated to keep rising.

• China's reliance on coal as a primary energy source has significantly contributed to its status as the world's largest emitter of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, and greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide.
• China's onshore oil resources are primarily located in the Northeast region and in the provinces of Xinjiang, Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan, Shandong, and Henan.
• Oil shale deposits are found in multiple locations, notably at Fushun in Liaoning, where they overlie coal reserves, and also in Guangdong.
• High-quality light oil has been discovered in the Pearl River estuary of the South China Sea, the Qaidam Basin in Qinghai, and the Tarim Basin in Xinjiang.
• Although China consumes most of its oil output domestically, it also exports some crude oil and oil products.
• China has explored and developed oil deposits in several maritime regions, including the South China Sea, East China Sea, Yellow Sea, Gulf of Tonkin, and Bohai Sea.
• In 2013, China's economic growth rate exceeded its domestic oil production capacity, and floods damaged the nation's oil fields mid-year, leading to increased oil imports.
• As a result, in September 2013, China surpassed the United States to become the world's largest importer of oil.
• The total extent of China's natural gas reserves remains unknown due to limited exploration efforts.
• Sichuan accounts for nearly half of China's known natural gas reserves and production.
• Most of China's natural gas is associated gas produced from major oil fields in the Northeast, especially the Daqing oilfield.
• Additional natural gas deposits have been identified in the Qaidam Basin, Hebei, Jiangsu, Shanghai, Zhejiang, and offshore southwest of Hainan.

• An article published in *Energy Economics* in 2011 by Mete Feridun (University of Greenwich) and Abdul Jalil (Wuhan University) states that China's financial development has not come at the expense of environmental pollution; instead, it has contributed to a decrease in pollution levels.
• The authors conclude that carbon emissions in China are mainly influenced by income levels, energy consumption, and trade openness.

• Their findings support the existence of an Environmental Kuznets Curve in China, indicating that environmental degradation initially increases with economic growth but decreases after reaching a certain income threshold.
• Global rare-earth-oxide production trends from 1956 to 2008, as reported by USGS, indicate significant changes in the supply and demand of these critical materials over the specified period.
• Iron ore reserves are distributed across most Chinese provinces, with notable deposits in Hainan, Gansu, Guizhou, southern Sichuan, and Guangdong provinces.
• The largest iron ore reserves are located north of the Yangtze River, primarily supplying neighboring iron and steel enterprises.
• China is well supplied with ferroalloys and manganese, with the exception of nickel, chromium, and cobalt, which are less abundant.
• Reserves of tungsten in China are considered to be fairly large, making the country a significant global supplier of this metal.
• Copper resources in China are moderate, with high-quality ore deposits found only in a few locations, including recent discoveries reported from Ningxia.
• Lead and zinc deposits are available within China, contributing to the country’s mineral resource base.
• Bauxite resources are believed to be plentiful, supporting China’s aluminum industry.
• China possesses the world's largest antimony reserves, making it the leading global supplier of this metal.
• Tin resources are abundant in China, with fairly rich deposits identified across various regions.

• Gold deposits are plentiful, and China ranks as the world's fifth-largest producer of gold; in the early 21st century, China became an important producer and exporter of rare metals used in high-technology industries.

• China produces a wide range of nonmetallic minerals, with salt being one of the most important, derived from coastal evaporation sites in Jiangsu, Hebei, Shandong, and Liaoning, as well as from extensive salt fields in Sichuan, Ningxia, and the Qaidam Basin.

• Significant deposits of phosphate rock are found in Jiangxi, Guangxi, Yunnan, and Hubei, with annual production accelerating each year; as of 2013, China produced approximately 97,000,000 metric tons of phosphate rock annually.
• Pyrites occur in several regions, with Liaoning, Hebei, Shandong, and Shanxi hosting the most important deposits.
• China has large resources of fluorite (fluorspar), gypsum, and asbestos.
• The country possesses the world's largest reserves and production capacity of cement, clinker, and limestone, supporting its extensive construction and infrastructure development.
• China Railway HXD1B is a high-speed train manufactured by CRRC, highlighting China's advancements in rail transportation technology.
• The CRRC Fuxing high-speed train is a prominent example of China's domestic manufacturing capabilities in high-speed rail.
• The C919 aircraft, developed by Chinese aerospace manufacturer Comac, signifies China's progress in commercial aviation industry.
• China holds a strong global position in the production of industrial goods, with several companies leading in steel, solar energy, and telecommunications accessories.
• As of 2024, industry constitutes 36.5% of China's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• From 2010 through at least 2023, China has produced more industrial goods than any other country worldwide.
• In 2023, China manufactures approximately 20% (one fifth) of the world's total industrial output.

• Major industrial sectors in China include mining and ore processing; iron and steel; aluminium; coal; machinery; armaments; textiles and apparel; petroleum; cement; chemical industries; fertilizers; food processing; automobiles and other transportation equipment such as rail cars, locomotives, ships, and aircraft; consumer products including footwear, toys, and electronics; and telecommunications and information technology.

• Since the founding of the People's Republic of China, industrial development has been prioritized, with 46% of the national output devoted to investment as of 2011, a proportion significantly higher than that of any other nation.
• The machine-building and metallurgical industries are among the most prioritized industrial branches, collectively accounting for approximately 20–30% of the total gross industrial output.

• Despite high output levels, innovation in Chinese industry has often been limited, with a system that rewards increases in gross output rather than improvements in product variety, sophistication, and quality.
• China continues to import significant quantities of specialized steels due to limitations in domestic innovation and production quality.
• Overall industrial output in China has grown at an average annual rate of over 10%, surpassing other sectors in terms of economic growth and modernization.
• After joining the World Trade Organization in 2001, China rapidly developed a reputation as the "world's factory," becoming a major exporter of manufactured goods.
• By 2019, China accounted for approximately 25% of all high-tech goods produced globally, reflecting the increasing complexity of its exports.

• The chemical industry in China primarily focuses on expanding the production of chemical fertilizers, plastics, and synthetic fibers, making China one of the leading global producers of nitrogenous fertilizers.

• The consumer goods sector emphasizes textiles and clothing, which are significant components of China's exports; textile manufacturing, increasingly dominated by synthetic fibers, accounts for about 10% of gross industrial output.
• The textile industry in China is geographically dispersed, with key centers including Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Harbin.
• There is a growing consumer culture within China, influencing industrial and manufacturing trends.

• As of 2024, China possesses substantial industrial capacity exceeding domestic demand, leading the government to promote capacity utilization abroad through initiatives such as the Belt and Road Initiative.
• In 2020, China produced over 1,053 million tonnes of steel, accounting for over half of the world's total steel production.
• China’s steel production in 2020 represented an increase of 5.6% compared to the previous year, despite a global decline of 0.9% in steel output.
• China’s share of global crude steel production rose from 53.3% in 2019 to 56.5% in 2020, but decreased by 2.1% in 2021.
• Iron ore production in China kept pace with steel production during the early 1990s but was soon surpassed by imported iron ore and other metals in the early 2000s.
• Steel production in China was approximately 140 million tons in 2000, increased to 419 million tons in 2006, and reached 928 million tons by 2018.
• In 2018, China was the world's top exporter of steel, with export volumes totaling 66.9 million tons, representing a 9% decrease compared to the previous year.
• Steel exports from China further declined in 2021 to 66.2 million tons, slowing the country's decade-long growth in steel exports.
• As of 2012, Chinese steel exports faced widespread anti-dumping taxes and had not yet returned to pre-2008 levels.
• Domestic steel demand in China remained strong, especially in the developing western regions such as Xinjiang, where steel production was expanding.
• Of the 45 largest steel-producing companies globally, 21 are Chinese, including the world's largest, China Baowu Steel Group.
• China is the world's largest automobile producer, manufacturing more than 31.28 million vehicles in 2024, with 5.86 million of those being exported overseas.
• As of 2024, China holds the status of the world's largest automobile market in terms of both sales and ownership.
• By 2006, China had become the world's third-largest automotive vehicle manufacturer, following the United States and Japan, and the second-largest consumer after the United States.
• In 2010, China surpassed the U.S. and Japan combined in vehicle manufacturing, producing more vehicles than both countries together.
• Automobile manufacturing in China has experienced rapid growth during the reform period:
• In 1975, only 139,800 automobiles were produced annually.
• By 1985, production increased to 443,377 units.
• In 1992, production reached nearly 1.1 million vehicles.
• By 2001, production had risen to 2.3 million.
• In 2002, production increased to nearly 3.25 million.
• In 2003, production jumped to 4.44 million.
• In 2004, production reached 5.07 million.
• In 2005, it increased to 5.71 million.
• In 2006, production was 7.28 million.
• In 2007, it was 8.88 million.
• In 2008, production was 9.35 million.
• In 2009, production surged to 13.83 million, establishing China as the world's number-one automaker.
• Domestic vehicle sales in China have kept pace with production, with passenger car sales experiencing significant growth in the early 2000s following steady increases in the late 1990s.
• In 2010, China became the world's largest automotive manufacturer and consumer, with an estimated 18 million new cars sold, overtaking the United States.
• China began exporting car parts in 1999 and planned major expansion into automobile and component exports starting in 2005.

• A notable example of export-oriented manufacturing is a Honda factory built in Guangzhou in 2004, dedicated solely to exports, with an expected shipment of 30,000 passenger vehicles to Europe in 2005.
• By 2004, twelve major foreign automotive manufacturers had joint-venture plants in China, producing a diverse range of vehicles including automobiles, minivans, SUVs, buses, and trucks.
• In 2003, China exported US$4.7 billion worth of vehicles and components.
• Vehicle exports increased from 78,000 units in 2004 to 173,000 units in 2005, and further to 340,000 units in 2006.
• Since 2020, China's vehicle exports have increased significantly, driven by the rise of new energy vehicles (NEVs).
• China overtook Germany in 2022 and Japan in 2023 to become the world's largest exporter of cars.
• The market for domestically produced cars under local brands is expected to continue growing both domestically and internationally.

• Freight transportation is predominantly handled by rail, which is monopolized by China Railway, with services varying widely across the network.
• In late 2007, China became one of the few countries to develop and launch its own indigenously produced high-speed train.

• Rail capacity struggles to meet the growing demand for transporting goods and raw materials such as coal, leading to rapid development of alternative transport modes including air routes, roads, and waterways to satisfy China's overall transportation needs.
• Some economic experts attribute China's relative economic growth compared to other emerging economies like Brazil, Argentina, and India to its early and substantial investment in infrastructure.
• During the 1990s and 2000s, China invested approximately 9% of its GDP in infrastructure development, whereas most emerging economies invested only 2% to 5% of their GDP.

• This substantial investment gap enabled China to grow under near-optimal conditions, while many South American economies faced development bottlenecks due to inadequate transportation networks, aging power grids, and mediocre educational systems.
• According to the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), China is the largest source of patent filings globally, contributing more than half of all patent applications worldwide.
• Over recent decades, science and technology development in China has experienced rapid growth, driven by government initiatives and societal emphasis.

• The Chinese government has prioritized science and technology as fundamental to the country’s socio-economic development and national prestige through targeted funding, reforms, and societal recognition.

• China has achieved significant advancements in various sectors, including education, infrastructure, high-tech manufacturing, artificial intelligence, academic publishing, patents, and commercial applications.
• The country is increasingly focusing on indigenous innovation to address and reform existing weaknesses in its technological ecosystem.

• China’s Thousand Talents Plan is a strategic initiative designed to attract innovative Chinese academics living abroad, as well as some foreign experts, to return to China and support its economic innovation objectives.
• A 2023 study by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute evaluated 44 critical technologies and concluded that China leads the world in 37 of them.
• Among the technologies in which China is a global leader are 5G internet, electric batteries, and hypersonic missiles.
